description: Borrowed from a Medieval Latin lixivio, lixiviatus, or formed from the root of lixivium, lixivia, from lixivius (“made into lye”), from lix (“ashes, lye”).

adjectives.description: lixiviate (comparative more lixiviate, superlative most lixiviate)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to lye or lixivium; of the quality of alkaline salts.
Impregnated with salts from wood ashes.
examples: but we cou'd not, by this way, discern the least acidity in our arsenical solution, but rather a manifest sign of an urinous or lixiviate quality

verbs.description: lixiviate (third-person singular simple present lixiviates, present participle lixiviating, simple past and past participle lixiviated)

entries.meaning: To separate (a substance) into soluble and insoluble components through percolation; to leach.
